reviewText:
A very interesting, unique, deceptively simple game.

Check out the game in action with my Build-A-Review

Pro:
_Nice, clean art style: Looks good with its own art style. Nice character portraits as well. Isn't really bombastic, but does look unique and coherent.
_Unique: The gameplay is something else altogether. It's hard to align this to any specific genre.
_Satisfying gameplay: It's very simple stuff, but clicking on tiles to explore them feels satisfying in the way that popping bubble wraps is satisfying, if that makes sense. It's like fapping, it's hard to explain, but try it for yourself and you'll see immediately why it's so great.
_Rogue-lite: It's a Rogue-like with persistent upgrades that effects your future runs. That was fun in Rogue Legacy, it's fun in here.
_Difficult: It's hard, but never truly feels unfair.
_Deceptively simple:  It's deceptively simple, but with an underlining devilishness that is very, very rogue-like. The game isn't afraid to troll you.
_Great pacing: Short runs (Lasts about 20-30 mins on average), but you'll be playing it over and over. It's really easy to lose track of time playing this game.

Cons:
_Could use more art assets: The art is nice, but there's not enough of it... I'll be honest, I'm just nit-picking here. I can't really think of anything negative to say.

Is it worth 10 bucks? You bet your sweet ♥♥♥. It's fun, unique, easy to pick up, hard to master. It's very addictive and interesting. Buy it, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Although the game is certainly rich both in interesting interactions as well as design flaws, it is hard not to recommend Runestone Keeper at its price point, which is set perfectly.

I will state this first: the game will repeatedly put you in positions where you are set to lose, without any possibilities of recovery. You will often look back from that point and realize that there was nothing you could have done to save yourself. It is expected that this does not frustrate you as you still progress" by spending the collected gold on upgrades afterwards.

As it currently stands
date: Runestone Keeper is a very accessible rogue-lite game that offers challenging experiences ranging from 10 to 30 minutes. It is alright at everything it does
recommended: your play sessions will sway rapidly between mild fun and curiosity and slight annoyance. Its distinguishment comes from the fact that even with its current flaws
hoursPlayed: it is very close to a very polished and satisfying experience.\n\nThe main weakness is balance and polish

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game. I really did. It looked like a really quirky new rogue-lite with a concept that was different, and different is often good when it comes to video games.

This concept, however, just doesn't work. In most Rogue-like games, there's a sense of things... mostly being your fault. It's your fault you didn't prepare for the goblin. It's your fault you drank a potion you shouldn't. It's your fault that you missed your jump.

In Runestone Keeper, the game decides more often than not if you live. You can't see any of the traps unless you're lucky enough to get access to an item that tells you-- most often, you end up finding traps by tripping them. There's no real sense of improvement-- just a hope that you click the right tiles and kill just enough enemies before you meet an untimely demise.

It doesn't feel like a game that rewards skill, it feels like a game that just tosses a coin. RNG plays too much of a role in the game for it to be truly enjoyable.

reviewText:
Sometimes the winning move is not to play. At least that's the feeling I get when I try to get through Runestone Keeper. As an adventurer, you must brave the depths in order to accomplish a thing. A lot of the story is in the background, and tends to crop up in random events. So you'll explore, find treasure, die, and repeat until you get bored.

I was planning on ignoring this game. Can you blame me? Just look at it. It's a rogue-like. When it comes to game-design, perma-death has been ran into the ground harder than zombies. Every freaking game wants to see me dead, my stuff taken away, my level reduced to 1, and my progress wiped away like it never ever happened. It's freakin' obnoxious, and yet I continue to play rogue-likes, because obviously I hate myself. As a bonus, this rogue-like resembles Minesweeper. Problem-solving! Strategizing! Clicking on stuff until you lose! It's all so terrible I want to vomit out of my nose.

As expected, it took me about a dozen hours of Runestone Keeper, just to figure out how much I hate it. There are some lovely aspects. The music is nice and atmospheric, the art is effective, and the simple click-to-explore interface removes a lot of the tedium. Also, unlike a number of rogue-likes, there's a shop where you can purchase permanent upgrades. The catch is that these upgrades increase your chances of something good happening. So after several play-throughs and investing hundreds of thousands of gold, your chances of survival might go up 2%. Thanks I guess.

Inside the dungeon, there are multiple floors. Exploration is as simple as clicking on a darkened tile. These tiles will reveal items, traps, mysterious shrines, monsters, shops, and other random events. Monsters are interesting in that they don't actively attack, unless you choose to fight them. The exceptions are the ranged monsters, who attack everytime you move. You could search the immediate area for items to help you deal with these evil denizens, but you run the risk of spawning creatures that boost stats, or cause any number of other problems. This aspect is pretty neat, as it forces you to weigh your options. Do you kill everything as they appear? Maybe you should explore and hope to stumble upon a healing item or a rare piece of armor.

I have nothing nice to say about traps in this game. Each floor is filled with them, and they will chew through your HP at a constant rate. There are items that reveal traps, but they're too infrequent. Most of the time, all you can do is click on the tiles, and pray you don't lose too much HP to spikes, falling rocks, bombs, poison, and so on. Sometimes I'll luck out and acquire a piece of armor that restores HP with every explored tile, but that's luck.

RNG is easily the most dominant force in this game, especially on the harder difficulties. While you have options such as spells, items, the gods you worship, and the stats you raise; they mean nothing when RNG decides to screw you. While exploring, I ran into an Overlord. The properties of an Overlord are random, but well let me just explain this particular jerk. This Overlord was a skeleton archer. His ability was that his attack level was equivalent to my HP. Once this guy appeared, I was ♥♥♥♥ out of luck. There are tools for dealing with this situation (like throwing knives, which insta-kill any ranged enemy), but I couldn't find anything of the sort. As I mentioned earlier, archers attack everytime you move, so they can't be avoided. Since the game is entirely turn-based, I had all the time in the world to think about how much I hate RNG. Along with a gigantic middle finger, I recieved an achievement entitled WTF".

WTF indeed.

Even if Lady Luck blesses you a hundred times over
date: you'll still have to contend with the end-boss. I've managed to reach him once. Apparently there are multiple end-bosses
recommended: and this phantom is the easiest of them. He has a big fat wad of HP

column22: 64 of 92 people (70%) found this review helpful 18 people found this review funny

reviewText:
It's impossible to review Runestone Keeper without mentioning its clear inspiration, Dungelot. I realise a lot of people are detached from the mobile world so the comparison will be lost on most but there is much more than a passing resemblance to Red Winter's series of tile-tapping dungeon crawlers. It splits the review down the middle; does it offer enough to fans of Dungelot to leave behind familiar stomping grounds and does it offer an interesting experience to those that are blissfully unaware of the games it draws upon?

Luckily, both questions have the same response. Yes.

The gameplay in Blackfire Games' Runestone Keeper is something of an amalgamation of Minesweeper, Dungeons of Dredmor and Desktop Dungeons. However, that's not to say it's that much like those games. Not very helpful, I know, but with the formula being shared only by two niche mobile predecessors, it becomes difficult to make comparisons you can relate to. Reviewers like to connect the dots between games so readers can quickly judge their interest yet that becomes pretty tough when it's a largely unique experience.

Dungeon floors are set out as a grid that can be explored in any order from your starting point, uncovering one tile at a time. Each step reveals one of many different thing, generally falling under a classification of good or bad. Most discoveries play out as you might expect; equipment offers stat boosts, traps affect you negatively and enemies invite you to turn-based combat. You can avoid most fights but monsters block adjacent squares and the key to the next floor is often in their clutches so you sometimes have to enter the fray.

Thankfully the game deals mostly in absolutes, so the RNG factor is kept to a minimum, certainly in battles. There's a percentage chance to hit that can frustrate but it can be counteracted with the right items, otherwise it's easy to predict how much damage you will take and if you'll win a certain encounter. Attack value hits your shields first, which absorb a certain amount of damage and then it hits your HP; very standard fare but familiarity can sometimes be comforting. There's enough creativity displayed in other elements to forgive the otherwise traditional combat system.

As easy as the gameplay seems, your first playthroughs will end pretty quickly and there's a temptation to deride Runestone Keep as being unfair and luck-based. It's true that some items are better to have than others but succeeding relies on how well you can adapt to the hand you are dealt. Finding those techniques that make short work of most foes is key, such as using Roar to disarm the foes that redirect damage twofold so that large mobs are destroyed in seconds. The plentiful traps may seem overwhelming but you're given many ways to avoid them, besides leaving a floor half-explored is often the smarter move. You will suffer your way through learning the ropes, much like most roguelikes, but the capability to win isn't locked behind a grind for XP, unlike Dungelot.

There's a wealth of layers to the gameplay, from a tattoo and enchantment system to the worshiping of deities and elite arena rooms. They're largely left unexplained which is a real shame as a poor decision can end a decent run, let alone cost incredibly precious runes. It does mean you'll be discovering new elements for many hours but a light tutorial in certain areas would have been greatly appreciated. The hint scrolls dotted around the levels tend to be obsolete by the time you pick them up. That said, the ability to right click anything to get a short description on the tiles properties is very helpful and you'll make use of it many times even once you are comfortable with the mechanics.

Once you've died more than a dozen times, discovered a few gods and know your way around the enemies and artifacts you encounter early on, the game finds itself a nice groove. It gives with one hand and rubs your nose in your mistakes with the other just like any good roguelike but it's far from perfect. An iffy translation is apparent regularly and the game can hang for a few seconds at times but it's largely bug free. There are some questions regarding its longevity though it's hard to say; maybe after a couple dozen hours the intrigue will slip, although that's a pretty reasonable lifetime given the price. The difficulty could be a little lower for some people, but then it's part of what defines the genre. Roguelikes have teeth and Runestone Keep is no exception. Sure, they're a little wonky but the smile is charming and once the fangs are in, you'll lose many hours to an unusual and rewarding little bruiser.

reviewText:
Before you buy this game, there is one thing you need to know:

Like many rogue like dungeon games, this one is quite hard and might cause frustration.

I'm not saying that it is bad, but the difficulty is part of the game play. Actually, this is probably one of the best rogue-like dungeon games I've ever played. From the game play to art, every part of it is worth the ten dollars I spent. It is true that there are still many bugs yet to be fixed and the characters and stats need some balence to be done. But as far as I know, the developers are working hard on improving the game. If you are a fan of rogue-like and have the patient to play a hard one, this game should end up on your must-play list.

9/10 - Please fix the bugs that some upgrades don't apply to the gameplay. I'm actually quite ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about that, since I actually saved up gold to unlock them.

p.s. valve, workshop support please, games like this will become something totally different with workshop support.

reviewText:
Truly a fun roguelike. And I consider it unique and certainly worth it's money.

However the gameplay is stiffling.
It's not a true roguelike, as some elements carry over between runs, namely runes, gold and shop unlockables.
Main problem are the runes, any rune collected and not used carries over to the next game, they are very powerful and rare. The key to success is to use the runes wisely. Additionally, many gamemodes (look up runewords) cost runes to play (most notably the endless runeword)

after your death, you can spend your gold in the shop to get passive upgrades to make the game slightly easier.

So what you end up doing is grinding. Grinding gold and runes in order to pay your expenses in a serious run, where you may want to play with a certain runeword, have prepared runes for certain gods you intend to worship and get tatoos from, and stock gold for certain items you hope to find in shops.

So when you do have a good run, you might not want to go all in in and spend your runes on the much neded tatoos in case you mess up and loose your entire investment.

What I want to recommend is a true roguelike, where every run is a chance to play it big, where you can play all in whitout having to grind for it on countless runs in advance.
Things this game regrettably isn't.

This is a different little game, a tile clicking/exploring game if you will.

You simply click unrevealed tiles on a dungeon level to reveal what's there.  It might be a monster, a trap, loot, health, or a great number of other things.  You continue searching each level trying to find both a key and a door to move down to the next, harder level of the dungeon.

Play continues like this until your health points run out and you die, at which point you see all your final stats including number of baddies killed and your final score for the game.

Because of the procedural generation, the Endless and Abyss modes that can be unlocked by beating the normal default game, this game offers a lot of value for the price it would seem from this early point in my experience with this game.

There are also shops and skill screens that can be unlocked which seem to offer more randomness and what is available to purchase when you unlock each of these by spending gold.  One you hit level 10, 15.. and so forth, you also open up new heros to explore the dungeons with.

All in all, it looks like a fun little game that doesn't require a ton of focus, doesn't require quick gaming reflexes, and offers a completely different game every time you'll play it.

I like it.  :-)

reviewText: If pixel-art, rouge-like, dungeon RPGs are your niche then this game is 100% spot on. I'm a big fan and avid player of many games that are a combination of or all of the mentioned genres and in particular the duneon genre games are beginning to blend together, making what had initially been a fun concept become bland and overdone repetitions.\nThis game may *seem* similar but it's a fairly simple, straightforward and, most importantly, a refreshing take on dungeon rpgs. Particular emphasis on simplicity, I never once felt like I was grinding through a floor or felt as though I had too much equipment to choose from. No option overload" with countless varieties of weapons/armor/shields with only slightly differing abilities nor endless labyrinths of areas to explore; it's quick
recommended: and it forces you to make decisions.\n\nEasy to get into and although difficult to master
hoursPlayed: you are mostly rewarded for your efforts. However there are plenty of "luck-of-the-draw" situations
voteText: so if you're the type to enjoy strategy over games of chance - you may be a bit frustrated or enraged at some of the randomization mechanics.\nLearning curve is a little tough at first: keeping track of buffs
votesHelpful: realizing that you accidentally sold back the equipment you just bought
votesTotal: finding out that trying to buy equipment after clearing the 1st floor is a waste of your reward since you can't use/afford anything
votesFunny: etc. Despite the initial confusion you learn the ropes quickly after dying a few times.\n\nOverall an excellent game

reviewText:
Runestone Keeper is a great game.

Until this was put on sale, I had on idea that such a game was in development. And now suddenly, it is proclaimed as the best made-in-China game of this year (and you could probably count in a few years before), to which I intend to agree. In that light, this game is a reason to celebrate, because for long I've doubted the abilities of any Chinese producers to make a decent game at all, let alone a roguelike game, which is of a quite modern concept that is much less established in the Chinese game indutries than in the western ones. But somehow, the developers succeeded to pull off this genre, and brought us Runestone Keeper.

RK still has its defects, e.g. imbalance of skills or equipments (some being too powerful and desirable, while some being totally expendable); relying heavily on luck to progress into deeper floors; and certainly we need more new monsters and mechanics to contantly overcome the unavoidable repititiveness. But overall, RK could nonetheless score at least an 8/10 from me, and many other players as well, I believe.

Having said all this, I'd put a recommend" label on RK as a conclusion
date: which is deserved without any doubt. And worth saying
recommended: the reason would not be "made in China but not cheap quality"
hoursPlayed: but "this is a good game after all".\n\nI hope the developers keep up with their efforts. As should many other Chinese developers
voteText: too."

reviewText:
Unfortunately the game potential is killed by randomness and WTF effects.

First time unknown event? Game over.
First time unknown mob (e.g. Gladiator)? Game over.
Trap level.. Trap level... Game over.
Bonus level (opened with the key), 2 elite ranged monters inside.. Game over.

I would forgive randomness if my choices would matter. They aren't.

Add to it bugs. Add to it slow progression or events which kills your progression (e.g. taking all your stacked for next +1% bonus money). Add to it lack of basic and not very basic info. Lack of previous experience game knowledges (there are dozens of even combinations which I doubt anyone able to learn, so basically same event in another game will lead to a different result.. to game over usually). Poor itemization. For whopping (kidding ofc) 26 hours I found yellow robe only once (!). You need luck to get a single peace of gear, not talking about gear-combos which are required to kill boss on easiest difficulty by gimp classes.

It wasn't bad at first, but then it all become pointless. Spending hours to get bad luck just before boss. Wizards level, then 2 ranged elites (god help) and then again ranged elite. How unlucky you have to be for this? Well, it happens 50% of time so not that much...

Not recommended, unless you get it for free or just want to spend maximum 2-3 evenings with beateful otherwise (in idea, not in how its done) casual-puzzle game.

Do not even try to play last difficulty. You need everything maxed, know everything and be very lucky which are unluckily to happens combination of factors, trust me.

reviewText:
A good roguelike that delivers what it promises.

Nice balance between simple mechanics (it plays with just the mouse) and different game possibilities according to which character you use.
It motivates you to play it over and over again to keep unlocking new characters and upgrades (a greater chance of finding runes, more souls for tile, better prices, etc.).
I just finished for the first time a dungeon in normal difficulty: it took me 22.5 hours, and I still have lots to unlock.
Furthermore, it has recently been upgraded, adding new characters, items and balance changes, which seems to point out that the developers are very much keeping it alive and interesting.

Recommended.

reviewText:
For a rogue like, it relies too much on RNG.
And the game is not balanced well, at all.

Each time you go down a floor, the monsters gain stat increases across the board compared to yourself.
You more often then not, don't get a single upgrade, sure you can find an item that gives a very minor bonus, or you level up for a single stat point, it doesn't matter by the time you get to lower floors as the enemies will always outscale you.
(even if we gain +1 to all 4 stats on level up, I still think the enemies will outscale you.)

Monsters with range get to attack without punity from your melee, yet if you try to use ranged vs melee, they still attack you. (why use a bow vs melee if they always get to stike back)
It is a flaw with the game mechancis, as the monsters do not move around.

No 'perk' or other system to help against traps (yea there are usable items, but nowhere near enough to render traps useless), beyond the weak upgrade shines that is near useless.

The upgrade shrine is really weak and is really expensive, I would have to play for dozens of hours to unlock them all. (and many are locked from how far I got).

The gods are wholey unblanced, ranging from useless, to useful (I only unlocked 5 of the 8 so far).

Ran into two bugs:
1. +hit% items only work for mainhand (yet +str items increase damage of both hands)
2. God of Rock supposed to +1 max life when picking up a heart, but it doesn't work when you have 100% health (you still the the default +5 instead of +6). (you have to be hurt to recieve it the +1 bonus)

And my best run, I literally died in one hit, down from 300+ health.
It was a mob that blows up for twice its attack damage, and it was an elite/boss version, with 140something attack.

After 5 hours of playng, I felt like I accomplished nothing. No other character unlocks, only a few upgrades in the upgrade shrine.
Because when you die, the only thing you keep is your gold and runestones.

reviewText:
The idea of a turn-based strategic roguelike game is very interesting-- all kinds of gameplay elements in this game, whether in your favor or not, are surprisingly fun to deal with.

One thing I'm not satisfied with is the steam cloud. I've installed this game on another PC using the same account, and the status file on the original PC turned out to be overwritten, so I ended up playing with the default character with no perks at all. This is somehow irritating.

Moreover, I believe this game still has a lot of things planned along with the weekly updates. The diversity of each randomly generated dungeon is still pretty much limited (though less variation gives way to tactics) at this moment, but I'm positive about the quality of dungeons-- It has got great potential. More efforts need to be steered in the direction of balancing stats, fixing bugs and adding more entities to the game.

reviewText:
Buy it on super sale, otherwise, NO.

Its fun for about...4 hours, then it becomes a no-fun-point-and-click-grind-athon.

I can't unlock any more characters... can't get past the...7th floor at best, even with upgrades (that seem to help very little). The rouge-like elements suck, quite honestly. The carry over of gold on most plays is in the double digits. Takes forever to buy upgrades that way. Super frustrating. I think I'm done. I feel like I MUST be doing something wrong for it to be this messed up but I'm completely out of patience to reseach what's wrong.

TL:dr:

I got it in a bundle, otherwise, I'd be REAL mad. As is, I'm only a little mad. I think I'm mostly mad because I loved it intensely at first, but then I felt like I hit a solid wall at about the 4 hour mark. Now, no progress, no fun, I'm done.

reviewText:
I really really wanted to like this game

It looks and plays like something I would LOVE

However, it has major design flaws that prevent it from being good.  Remember ski free?  This is very similar to that.  You can only get so far in the game before it throws something at you that is completely unavoidable.  In other games a bad roll will merely make it difficult for you but with skill you can prevail.  Not in this game.  In runestone keeper, a bad roll means instant death.

The game plays a little bit like minesweeper and you attack enemies by clicking on them.  The bottom left is their attack power and the bottom right is their HP.  Sometimes an enemy will appear that is out of your range and the only way you can attack them is if you have a range weapon or are next to them.  If you are playing a melee character, then you are SOL because that enemy will attack you until you get next to it.  I just died because the floor had 5 ranged enemies.  They only had 3 attack power each so no big deal right?  Well...a few clicks later the floor revealed an ELITE (meaning no items or magic work on it) range enemy with 110 ♥♥♥♥ing attack.

Just to put that in perspective...You start the game with 31hp.  I had killed every enemy on every floor at that point to level up my str and hp as much as possible.  In addition, I worshipped a power god that gave me a ton of strength.  I used up two gold runestones to get an additional 30+ HP points each so I was at 130 hp at the time.  I was at full health when I entered that floor.  In other words, I had gotten very very lucky up to that point.  And I still died and I had absolutely no way of preventing it.

Think about that.  I got as lucky as you can get and did everything I could to be as strong and as defensive as possible and I was only on the 7th floor.  A RANGE enemy with 110 attack????  THERE IS NO WAY TO SURVIVE THIS.  THIS IS POOR DESIGN.

just look at this ♥♥♥♥ and decide for yourself if you want to play this game
http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197964342785/screenshots/?appid=339400

reviewText:
This game is very addicting first off. It is different from other rogue-likes that I have played in the past. There is no character that shows you where you are moving to, but once you get used to that it is a very deep and strategic rogue-like that rivals those out there today.

I thoroughly enjoyed my time playing it and find myself going back to it for a few hours of fun each time. The one downside I will say about the game is because of the limited art style, I find the game to be pretty repetative, which may turn others off to the experience.

I have started a Let's Play series on this game to show you the game itself, the art style, and how I play. If you would like, please give it a watch. Thank you!

reviewText: Clicking on squares can only be entertaining for so long. Gameplay consists of just clicking squares randomly on the same, square-shaped grid map over and over and over again. Each space you click might contain nothing, or it might contain a monster, a dead end, unavoidable damage, or one of the game's items (most of which are pretty useless). You might also find a shop with items too expensive to afford. Every rare once in a while, some sort of story event takes place in which a paragraph will appear and ask you to make a choice after reading it. The two stories I saw were written in English so badly broken that I had no idea which option to take. All in all, it's a little too simplistic and unpolished for a $10 price tag.

reviewText:
I just picked up the game and played about 7 hours straight. So far it is very fun, hard as nails, and a little frustrating due to RNG.
While it is a roguelike, it is not as difficult as some to pick up. After the tutorial, it didn't take long to get a handle on the basic mechanics,
I recommend for people who like difficult games and roguelikes.
For the price, I have to recomend it highly.

reviewText: Relatively easy to learn the basics, except perhaps what the runes are and do (ironically).\n\nStarting a new character has it start from scratch and it has its own progression, but you can also unlock other things permanently. Such as, gods available to worship from the start, an item shop, permanent passive upgrades to your characters, and so on. So, a round where you die doesn't have to feel completely in vain.

reviewText: A novel, pocket-size Rogue-lite that might once have been titled Minesweeper Quest; a feature-complete dungeon crawler conveying the full suite of CRPG trappings with originality and insight. Save for some slightly stilted event dialogue, the presentation is excellent, ably negotiating between gratuitous low-fidelity and unimaginative modern rendering. A thoroughly interesting way to engage with a well-worn (and profoundly frustrating) genre concept.

reviewText: This has become my go-to roguelike (well, this and HyperRogue), but it is very different from others in that you uncover tiles instead of actually moving a character; so it has more a feel of a puzzle than an adventure, but this also makes it simpler to play than most. This also means that ranged combat is non-directional - the monster will just fire" at your character sheet..."

reviewText:
Very good art on this game, built upon a minesweeper-esque tactical game turn-based premise that seems like it would be compelling. I've had major comebacks that turned into run completions due to good desicion making, as well as great desicion making that just fell flat on it's face. Such is the roguelike. It fits the bill. I'm a roguelike ♥♥♥♥♥, so of course I bought it.

Alright then, so why the downvote? Let's ignore the lazy UI, typos, ambiguious stats, and uncompelling quest events for the moment.

So when a designer anylizes a game that they've made, they don't always ask themselves what's the design space of this game?" and subsequencially
date: "At what point am I forcing players to play the 'grindy' part of my game to reach milestones before the design space caps out?"\n\nThis game attempts to milk playtime out of the user by making them farm gold and runestones
recommended: running the dungeon over and over again to accumilate these scarce resources in hopes to make future games better (and options accesable). On the whole
hoursPlayed: I'm not in disagreement with this playstyle
voteText: but using these resources is a total crapshoot. You can blow the entirity of your runestone payload on a playthrough that slams you at level five for reasons beyond your control
helpfulPercent: leaving you feeling cheated for making a desicions that not only had very little impact on play
votesTotal: just things you farmed up in between.\n\nThis drop rate is just not satisfactory compared to the content the game actually has to offer
votesFunny: and is a lazy design choice
commentsCount: and the limited design space does given much room for gameplay expnasion. The solution should not be 'farm'. This isn't an MMO; It's minesweeper. You can only milk so much gameplay out of it. If you're going to make a score attack mode
column16: don't make people farm for the opportunity to play that mode
column17: just have them unlock the option once.\n\nNow add in all that stuff up top that I said to ignore
column19: stuff that should be implimented in alpha and
column21: beta tested fixed. Keyboard controls. Documentations on those controls. Icons for crucial monster abilities. What the ♥♥♥♥ the luck stat does. These are 2-10 minute fixes a peice.\n\nNo
column22: I do not recomend this game
column23: especially not for $15. This is a $5 game

reviewText: Fun and satisfying time-killer. But... my god is the text poorly translated. So much so that it almost kills the immersive atmosphere. Almost every piece of text has some pretty bad grammar mistakes. So bad sometimes that the text just doesn't make any sense. Otherwise it's satisfying, RNG- filled fun.

reviewText: A bare-bones roguelike with a legacy system. To progress, you reveal tiles on a square grid, which can hide monsters, traps, usable items or various shops. Your character does not have an avatar, and monsters do not move around; attacking an enemy is simply done through clicking it. This results in fast-paced gameplay, which makes the game surprisingly addictive. There are loot drops, a magic system, gods to worship for various bonuses, and random quest events, which are always a series of dialog choices that can result in good or bad outcomes.\n\nI do recommend the game, but caution that it contains some very strong RNG. There's no way to avoid all the traps, and some levels are just paved with toxin traps that will quickly build up to a lethal does, and you will die. Sometimes there are ranged boss monsters with as much attack as your health that will literally oneshot you no matter how healthy or well-equipped you are, and if you dont happen to have an instakill item, you will die. Those elements taint an otherwise tough, but relatively fair game.
